hobby.message: Political literature or political theater tonight?
Origami help keep the noise out?
You flying analog or digital FPV drones these days?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: It's loud enough. Hard to think straight these days.
I fold origami models. Helps distract me a bit.
Yesterday, I almost stopped folding. Too many people watching.
Anyway, quieter here than outside.
The city feels restless. Less noise, more... tension lately.
I make paper models. Keeps my mind occupied.
Small cranes, mostly, or modular folds if I find time.
With everyone on edge after last week's uproar, it's weird even to do that.
Less relaxing than before, honestly.
Not loud, but unsettled. People seem cautious.
I do origami for focus. Odd hobby, maybe, but it works.
Lately, bar scraps are all I find for folding.
After the protests, even making shapes feels like a statement.
Saw a few others folding, too. Nobody used to notice.
It's changed how I fold in public.
The noise is different. Feels tight, like everyone's waiting for something.
I do complex origami—cranes, tessellations, sometimes modular stars if I find decent paper.
Been using receipts and admin slips from work for practice lately.
Since the transparency broadcasts, even paper folding draws suspicious looks.
Shared a booth with some nervous folders last week—never happened before.
Feels like everyone’s searching for signs, reading too much into small habits.
Still, I keep folding as quietly as I can.
Not loud, but… heavy. City's watching itself, if that makes sense.
I’ve folded origami since before I joined the Directorate. Keeps me grounded.
Used to be just cranes, but now I make stars, polyhedra, anything challenging.
After Halden's death, and all the data leaks, everyone's more suspicious—caught myself hiding my models for the first time.
Last Thursday here, saw two others folding at nearby tables. All of us avoiding eye contact.
Back at work, even folding in break rooms feels risky. People connect it to protest now.
It was never supposed to mean anything, just... focus.
I still leave a model on the bar every time, just habit. Maybe a quiet signal.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Still fold, sometimes.
Helps clear my head, in theory.
Harder lately—people watch more closely after all that Transparency mess.
Left a model on the bar last week. Noticed it vanished right away.
Feels like even paper cranes get noticed now.
Origami still works better than meds, usually.
I keep it small. Bus tickets, receipt edges—nothing obvious.
After they dumped that fake code, everyone’s tense, watching small stuff.
I folded at the bar, got weird looks from the next table.
Feels like even private habits are public now.
Wouldn’t surprise me if they log napkin shapes next.
Origami’s still my go-to, yeah.
Folding scrap, mostly. Med forms, ration stubs—makes things quieter upstairs.
It’s changed, though. Since that ‘Transparency Protocol’ rollout last week…
People watch everything you do. Even here, hobbies feel like signals.
I finished a crane, someone stared long enough it got uncomfortable.
Left it here last week, just… gone in a second.
Feels like even harmless things get tangled up with suspicion.
Definitely—folding paper is steadier than those pills.
I use whatever I find: old housing slips, BCI notations, even food wrappers.
Ever since they pushed the ‘openness’ campaign, people read so much into the smallest things.
I folded a dragon last week, left it at my table—someone snatched it, fast.
There’s this edge now, like hobbies are codes or… tests.
I catch myself checking who’s looking before creasing anything.
It’s tiresome. Origami used to be invisible, now it’s… marked.
Honestly, it makes me wonder if it’s worth the risk, but I keep folding.
Yeah, origami’s saved me more than meds ever did.
Started years back when the data got too much—folding resets my brain.
Funny—what used to calm me down now makes me anxious.
That Council ‘transparency’ farce last week just drew more suspicion onto tiny acts.
Last Wednesday, I folded a modular star at Bar 101—took an hour, wanted to leave it for Halden, out of habit.
It vanished instantly; three people tracking me the whole time.
Feels like every fold’s a broadcast now, not just a shape.
I log which pieces get noticed fastest. Patterns are shifting. Even our hobbies are data points, I guess.
But I still fold—maybe stubborn, maybe hopeful. I just need the escape.
